column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/yall-got-to-keep-sheps-head-clear/|“Y’all Got To Keep Shep’s Head Clear”|So who is the Bucs’ leader in dumb penalties this season? column2: uplifting teammates with boundless spirit and passion. Shepard was like that during his eight years with Giants
column6: a huge number for his position. “Shep” has one each for unnecessary roughness
column8: unsportsmanlike conduct and illegal motion. Buccaneers running back Rachaad White joined SiriusXM NFL Radio this week and noted that players have been told to keep Shep’s mind right. “He plays furious and he plays ferocious
column10: ” White said of Shepard. “And you love a guy like that
column11: and it gets to the point where coaches when we get to gameday be like
column12: ‘Y’all got to keep Shep’s head clear. You all got to keep him calm’ and things like that. But no. That’s not how you play football. It’s a violent game. “It’s a crazy game. You got to be crazy to play this game. That’s just the reality of it
column13: or have some craziness in you. So

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/mike-evans-impact-on-offense-huge/|Mike Evans’ Impact On Offense “Huge”|If you thought the Bucs offense looked different Sunday against the Giants than in recent games
column2: you are not alone. Joe thought the same. A big reason was future Hall of Fame receiver Mike Evans returned to the field
column4: depending on who is talking. The offense just looked sharper

column6: Joe asked Bucs offensive Liam Coen what sort of impact Evans’ return brought after missing three games with a bum hamstring
column7: suffered in the loss to Baltimore. “Huge
column8: huge!” Coen said. “Just his presence alone
column10: what you can at times dictate in terms of what kind of defensive structure you’re going to get.” It wasn’t just the X’s and O’s element where Evans made an impact
column13: is contagious. “The players draw confidence” [from Evans]
column14: Coen added. An area of the field Coen had planned to attack against the Giants just so happens to be an area where Evans shines. “His ability to go win one-on-one routes and give us some plays down the field — more so in that intermediate range where we were trying to get into this past week
column15: ” Coen said. Evans is “such a good dude. It’s always good to have him back.” The way the offense was so sharp with Evans back gave Joe hope that running the table in the final six weeks isn’t as crazy as Joe previously believed. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/liam-coen-says-he-is-not-coaching-baker-mayfield-to-block-40-yards-downfield/|Liam Coen Says He Is Not Coaching Baker Mayfield  To Block 40 Yards Downfield|Joe doesn’t think there is a football fan alive who didn’t think it was cool to see Baker Mayfield being the lead blocker for Bucky Irving Sunday at midfield. But just like watching a running back or receiver try to hurdle a defender
column3: but it also may not be smart. And that is the fine line Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen walks. He loves Mayfield’s heart and hustle. He loves how Mayfield is trying to be a team guy. But Coen also confessed he and the Bucs need Mayfield for the playoff push and not to get lit up by a linebacker. This morning at One Buc Palace
column4: Coen was asked if he coaches Mayfield to race downfield to block. Coen smiled broadly as he enjoyed the play too. You can tell by the way he answered that he’s not overly fond of Mayfield trying to be a lead blocker. But
column6: Mayfield’s downfield blocking is a form of what Coen preaches to his players: Be a team guy and give full effort. “No
column8: ” Coen said denying the Bucs actually work on Mayfield’s downfield blocking. “Our thought process as a unit is to play for each other. “That’s all we talk about. What you put on tape
column9: your teammates are going to see. Everybody is going to see. “So if you put kind of crummy effort on tape and you get an oppotunity to get a block on somebody for your buddy and you don’t do it
column11: they might look at you a little funky.” Coen said Mayfield racing downfield to be a lead blocker is just in Mayfield’s DNA. “I do think it is a product of him and how he is wired and the person he is
column12: ” Coen said. “But [Mayfield] is to exemplify how we want to play the game on offense.” Again
column13: it looks cool. And Joe is fully convinced effort like that from a quarterback stokes teammates
column14: not just on offense but the defense
column15: too. Last year in the season-opening win at Minnesota
column16: Mayfield ran for a key first down where he bullied his way through a tackle to get it. You could see the defense in the background erupt in delight that their quarterback was selling out to help them secure a win. That type of play is contagious
column17: but also dangerous. The Bucs don’t need to try to make the playoffs with a quarterback who has thrown but 10 passes in his three-year career. Ira Kaufman Talks Lineup Change

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/conor-orr-doubts-todd-bowles-is-on-solid-ground/|Conor Orr Doubts Todd Bowles Is On Solid Ground|This is interesting to Joe
column3: the core of the story. SI NFL columnist Conor Orr was a guest along with James Palmer on the “Heed the Call” podcast hosted by NFL.com expatriates Dan Hanzus and Marc Sessler. Palmer
column5: is an NFL Media refugee. There
column6: the quartet decided to take a look at the job security of all 32 NFL coaches. Each had different takes and views on coaches thought to be safe or on a roasting hot seat. When it came to the perceived status of Bucs coach Todd Bowles
column7: it grew very interesting for Joe. Bowles’ name was included in the category of “Likely Bullet Proof.” Hanzus rattled off the names in this group only stopping when someone wanted to interject a comment. When Hanzus read off “Bowles
column8: ” Orr raised his hand to offer pushback. “I think I’d kick him down one [level]
column9: ” Orr said. “I think we have to have a good back-end to the season here.” Palmer asked Orr
column10: “Can you see a good back-end to the season? Because I can.” Orr agreed. “I can
column11: ” Orr said. “That’s the thing. The schedule is excellent. Everything is breaking. I do think they will win that division. “But
column12: I think it is unignorable that this idea of
column13: maybe over the last two seasons
column16: maybe they may want to go in a different direction.’ But they keep winning and hanging on.” Hanzus also sided with Orr. “I’m with you
column17: ” Hanzus said. So Bowles was bumped to a lower group “We Need To Show Progress.” Why does this interest Joe? Let’s connect a few dots
column18: shall we? Joe attends NFL media events like the combine and Super Bowl Opening Night/media week. Orr also is there talking to NFL shot-callers
column23: sometimes owners over drinks in bars or burgers at places like Steak n’ Shake in downtown Indianapolis. Jerry Jones
column25: is more than happy to have a bourbon and talk turkey with reporters. Off the record
column26: of course. Joe once saw Packers president Mark Murphy at Steak n’ Shake taking care of his late-night munchies grabbing grub near midnight
column27: just like any other schlub. Very approachable. So
column28: this is to say Joe knows Orr talks to a lot of NFL people. So the reference to “chatter” perked up Joe’s ears. Now
column31: who Joe knows is very well-plugged in with NFL heavy hitters
column32: posted a story for The Athletic claiming her intel from NFL coaches and suits says Bill Belichick’s name comes up “frequently” linking him to the Bucs. And yes
column33: Joe fully understands Bowles is still employed. But with this “chatter
column34: ” now from two sources in recent days who know their way around the NFL media playground
column35: if Bowles can’t lead the Bucs to the playoffs with what so many perceive as a cotton-candy-soft schedule over the next six weeks

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/creative-offense-from-liam-coen/|Creative Offense From Liam Coen|Byron Leftwich could never! Really creative
column2: fun stuff here from Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen. So let’s think about it: If it is smart to get the ball into the hands of your best players (it is)
column3: who are they on the Bucs offense? Well
column5: sure. Cade Otton? Don’t forget about him. And yeah
column6: Rachaad White is a serious weapon in the passing game. So why not get all four of them on the field at once? That’s what Coen is trying to do. Evan Closky of WTSP-TV Channel 10 broke down tape of the Bucs’ win Sunday in the New Jersey Swamplands. He shows ways Coen uses those four weapons at the same time. Coen likes to call Irving and White in the backfield at the same time “Pony.” Often
column7: Coen had Irving line up at receiver
column8: which should really throw off a defense. Will Irving run a jet sweep? Will Irving go out on pass routes? Would the Bucs fake a run up the middle with White and pitch to Irving coming off the edge? Lots of fun possibilities from these formations. And this is just one of a few reasons why “this Joe” is pretty confident Coen will be a head coach somewhere in the lower-48 next season.  |2024-11-27 03:45:00|216|13|7.5|Liam Coen|Creative offensive strategies showcased with Bucs' key players.|5|Varied sentiments
